events.title: Eta Aquariid Meteor Shower - Star Shower from Halley's Comet!
events.description:
The name might sound complicated, but let's break it down! 'Eta Aquariid' comes from the constellation Aquarius (the Water Bearer) and the star Eta Aquarii where the meteors seem to come from. 'Meteor Shower' means lots of shooting stars appearing at once!

The Eta Aquariids are like fireworks in the sky! These meteors come from tiny pieces of ice and dust left behind by Halley's Comet (yes, the famous one!). When Earth passes through this debris trail, these particles burn up in our atmosphere, creating beautiful streaks of light across the sky.

Think of it like this: When you drive through rain, raindrops hit your windshield, right? Similarly, as Earth moves through space, it hits these tiny comet particles, and they burn up like shooting stars!

This shower can produce 50-60 meteors per hour at its peak - that's almost one every minute! The best viewing time is before dawn on May 6th. In 2025, the Moon will set before morning, giving us nice dark skies for watching.

To see them: Find a dark spot away from city lights, bring a blanket or chair to lie back on, and look toward the constellation Aquarius in the eastern sky. No telescope needed - just your eyes!
events.shortDescription: See shooting stars from Halley's Comet! Up to 50-60 meteors per hour peak on May 6th.

images.altText: Sky map showing the Aquarius constellation
Sky map showing the Aquarius constellation

events.title: New Moon - Perfect for Stargazing!
events.description:
The 'New Moon' means the Moon is completely invisible in the night sky! It's when the Moon is between Earth and the Sun, so we can't see the part that's lit up.

The New Moon is when the Moon is between Earth and the Sun, making it invisible to us. This creates the darkest skies of the month - perfect for watching stars!

Imagine turning off all the lights in your room to see better - that's what the New Moon does for the night sky. Without moonlight, we can see fainter stars, galaxies, and even the Milky Way if you're in a dark area.

This New Moon happens on May 8th, creating ideal conditions for watching the Eta Lyrid meteor shower (which peaks on May 10th).
events.shortDescription: Darkest skies of the month! Perfect for stargazing on May 8th.

images.altText: Diagram showing Earth, Moon, and Sun positions during New Moon
Dark sky without moon, showing Milky Way

events.title: Eta Lyrid Meteor Shower - Midnight Sky Show
events.description:
This shower's name comes from 'Eta Lyrae' (a star in the constellation Lyra) and 'meteor shower' which means falling stars!

The Eta Lyrids are like the quieter cousin of the Eta Aquariids. Instead of 50 meteors per hour, you might see about 3 meteors per hour. They come from the constellation Lyra (the Harp).

Think of it like popcorn popping in the microwave - instead of a constant stream, you'll see occasional bursts of light. Each meteor is still special though!

The best viewing time is after midnight on May 10th, when the constellation Lyra is high in the sky. The New Moon on May 8th means the sky will be extra dark for perfect viewing.
events.shortDescription: Smaller but beautiful meteor shower from Lyra constellation, May 10th.

images.altText: Eta Lyrid meteor over the night sky

events.title: Moon-Mars-Beehive Cluster: A Cosmic Triangle!
events.description:
Let me explain this title! 'Conjunction' means celestial objects appear close together in the sky. Mars is a planet, and the Beehive Cluster is a group of stars named because they look like bees buzzing around!

On the night of May 3-4, you'll see three cool things close together in the sky: the Moon, Mars, and the Beehive Cluster (a group of stars that looks like a swarm of bees).

Imagine drawing a triangle in the sky - that's what these three objects will look like! Mars will appear as a reddish dot, the Moon will be nearly half-full, and with binoculars, you can see the Beehive Cluster as a fuzzy patch of stars.

It's like our cosmic neighbors are having a party! Look in the Cancer constellation in the evening sky after sunset.
events.shortDescription: See the Moon, Mars, and Beehive Cluster together on May 3-4.

images.altText: Moon, Mars, and Beehive Cluster arrangement

events.title: Venus: The Morning Star Returns!
events.description:
Let's break down the title! Venus is a planet (Earth's neighbor), 'Morning Star' means it appears before sunrise, and 'elongation' describes how far Venus is from the Sun in our sky!

Venus is about to become the 'Morning Star' again! Usually we see Venus in the evening sky (as the 'Evening Star'), but on May 31st, it reaches its farthest point east of the Sun.

Think of Venus like a friend who sometimes stays up late with you (Evening Star) and sometimes gets up early (Morning Star). Right now, it's switching from its evening routine to its morning one!

Venus is the brightest planet in our sky - so bright you can sometimes see it during the day! Look for it low in the eastern sky about 45 minutes before sunrise.
events.shortDescription: Watch Venus return as the bright Morning Star on May 31st.

images.altText: Diagram showing Venus at greatest elongation

events.title: Flower Moon (Micromoon) - A Smaller Full Moon
events.description:
The Full Moon on May 12th is nicknamed the 'Flower Moon' because it happens when spring flowers are blooming. This one is also a 'Micromoon' - when the Moon is farther from Earth, making it appear slightly smaller than usual.

Imagine holding two coins - a penny and a nickel. The difference between a Micromoon and a regular Full Moon is like the difference between those coins. You probably won't notice it's smaller unless you compare photos!

The Moon will still light up the night sky beautifully, and it's safe to look at without special equipment.
events.shortDescription: Full Flower Moon appears slightly smaller on May 12th (Micromoon).

images.altText: Comparison between Micromoon and regular Full Moon
